item.title: Tortured by al Qaeda, He Saw Same Craziness in Capitol Rioters...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
Jim Cole/APAfter they locked his body into a truck tire. After they cuffed his hands behind his back, then flipped him over so his weight rested on his knees and forehead. After they poured water over him, then beat his feet and hands with steel cables. That‚Äôs when Theo Padnos confessed to helping the CIA kill Islamic terrorist Anwar al-Awlaki, to being gay, to helping the CIA get the goods on al Qaeda in Syria, and to his desire to rape Syrian women.None of this was true.‚ÄúThe ideal torturer in an Islamic state is someone who takes himself out of the act entirely,‚Äù says Padnos, whose new book, Blindfold: A Memoir of Capture, Torture and Enlightenment, tells of the nearly two years he was held as a prisoner by al Qaeda in Syria. ‚Äú[The torturer] does his bit without emotion. The vast majority of them thought of torture as work they had to do to purify Syria of bad elements that had crept into the nation during the time of the Assads.‚ÄùPadnos, a writer who spoke Arabic, went to Syria in late 2012 with the aim of rambling along the Syrian-Turkish frontier and reporting about how the uprising against the Assad regime was affecting the average citizen. He had been to Syria in the past, had even studied at an Islamic religious school in Damascus. But the Syria he had known no longer existed, and in the book he is the first to admit that his under-estimation of the situation in 2012, and his lack of a press pass‚Äîhe had no assignment‚Äîwas what got him into trouble.Detainees Describe an American Presence in Their Torture Chambers‚ÄúI thought I knew Syria so well that I could get along with everybody,‚Äù says Padnos. ‚ÄúBut obviously, the whole country was in the process of a radical psychological transformation. Something had happened in the countryside that had changed the whole complexion of the society.‚ÄùPadnos decided to sneak into Syria from Antakya, Turkey, with a group of men he thought were smugglers. But those companions kidnapped him, and eventually he was turned over to Jebhat al-Nusra, the Syrian al Qaeda franchise. Thrown into a cell in the basement of the Aleppo eye hospital, Padnos began an odyssey that saw him transferred to the basement of a villa, then a grocery store, a warehouse basement, a basement of Aleppo‚Äôs motor vehicles department, a janitor‚Äôs closet, a cell in a farmhouse, and towards the end of his captivity, a plush villa where he was given some small freedoms and was essentially under house arrest. Throughout all this he was tortured on a regular basis and referred to by his captors with such charming names as Pig, Donkey, Insect, and Filth.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a psychological sense of terror and despair‚Äù about situations like this, says Padnos. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know how long it will go on, and where it‚Äôs going. They can drag it out for months.‚Äù But, he adds in the book, ‚Äúonce you know the rules, life in our society, even in its worst places, in which, I‚Äôm pretty sure, I lived, was bearable.‚ÄùPadnos says his kidnappers told him they hated the West because of its arrogance, its preoccupation with sex, and its alleged submission to the Jews. Some wanted to establish an age-old Islamic dream, where Muslims would live in harmony with the land and themselves, invincible before Islam‚Äôs enemies, and at one with the Koran. Padnos admits that some of their grievances made sense, that ‚Äúthey feel oppressed in their own countries. A major grievance is that Islam as a religion is not the power it once was, it does not provide justice as it once did.‚ÄùIn this respect, the longing for a purer, more just Islamic society mirrors in some ways the anger of the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. ‚ÄúThe major comparison is the radicalization of normal people,‚Äù says Padnos. ‚ÄúWhat happened in Syria is that huge swaths of the population became radicalized. Most of these MAGA guys, they believe they are on a spiritual quest to make America great. They have surrendered themselves to some authority they really don‚Äôt understand. Here it‚Äôs Donald Trump, over there it‚Äôs ISIS. It‚Äôs the crowd element that is frightening.‚ÄùDuring his time in captivity, Padnos became used to what he calls ‚Äúwelcoming parties‚Äù‚Äîthe beatings he received when entering a new prison‚Äîand began to think of his constant attempts to rid himself of lice as a ‚Äúleisure activity.‚Äù He came to realize that his guards were often bored, and to relieve their boredom, they abused him. He also had an extremely contentious relationship with one fellow cellmate, Matt Schrier, a photojournalist who converted to Islam while in prison.‚ÄúMatt hated me because I had refused to convert, because I felt I was more than willing to find the good in an al Qaeda suicide bomber than I was to spend a moment in conversation with him, and because I knew the secret of his bad faith. (Schrier has admitted his conversion to Islam improved relations with his kidnappers).‚ÄùPadnos was finally released in August 2014, thanks to a ransom paid by the Qatari government which, he says, ‚Äúprobably started the problem; they sent in a lot of weapons to Syria that wound up in the hands of the radicals. They had this idea of sponsoring a revolution in Syria [but] they armed the people who tortured me.‚Äù Padnos was forced to rely on Qatari largesse because the United States has a policy of not negotiating with terrorists, something the former prisoner gets angry about when the subject is brought up.‚ÄúI negotiated with terrorists every day,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI had no moral qualms about talking to anybody if it was about saving the life of an American citizen. The U.S. will talk to them, but they will not make any concessions to terrorists.‚ÄùYou can understand why Padnos feels that way‚Äîany hostage probably feels the same‚Äîand still disagree with him. But there are more important, and more sobering, lessons that Padnos wants readers to take away from Blindfold: ‚ÄúI want readers to see that a strange psychological phenomenon has taken over vast swaths of the landscape. They called it a caliphate, I call it mass craziness. It‚Äôs The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale, a nightmare society where women are sex slaves and people are tortured in the public square.‚ÄùStill, Padnos made it back home to Vermont safely, and says that if nothing else, the experience made him understand ‚Äúhow fragile life is. I got a second chance to live, and I will not take such cavalier risks in my life again. I came through this happier than I was before, eager to live life.‚ÄùRead more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day. Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you. Learn more.

item.title: Worst Awards Ever Completely Botched Scandal...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
Getty ImagesIt‚Äôs not news that the Golden Globes, as an awards show, are a bit of a joke. But, my, has that joke gone stale.The joke resurfaces every few years, sometimes from the ceremony‚Äôs stage itself. In 2016, host Ricky Gervais dinged them as ‚Äúworthless,‚Äù likening the honor to ‚Äúa bit of metal that some nice old confused journalists wanted to give you in person so they could meet you and have a selfie with you.‚ÄùTina Fey and Amy Poehler hosted Sunday night‚Äôs ceremony in unprecedented times: Because of the pandemic, each emceed from a different coast with a few dozen celebrity presenters and only masked first responders in the audience.And because of controversy surrounding the legitimacy and inclusivity of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which votes on the awards, they were hosting in the face of serious backlash and even a boycott. Many celebrities ahead of Sunday night shared a #TimesUpGlobes graphic with the mission statement ‚Äúa cosmetic fix isn‚Äôt enough,‚Äù following the revelation that the group has not a single Black member in its ranks of 87.Ahead of Sunday‚Äôs telecast, a pre-show hosted on NBC by This Is Us‚Äôs Susan Kelechi-Watson and The Weakest Link‚Äôs Jane Lynch teased that the HFPA would be making a statement about its non-inclusive membership during the telecast. They plugged it as a reason to tune in, like the Grammys would hype a performance by Beyonc√© or the Emmys would an Oprah speech. Where a sheepish tone or atonement would be expected, the telecast seemed instead to choose opportunism‚Äîand, more pathetically, it even failed at that, as became clear when the promised statement finally came.It took only about three minutes for Fey to make the first joke about the controversy in her opening monologue, with presenters Sterling K. Brown and Kelechi-Watson as well as winner Sacha Baron Cohen later ridiculing the organization from its own stage. Still, it was the HFPA that did what it has done best for decades: reveal its own punchline, apparently not understanding the laugh was at its own expense.That was this case this year when it nominated Netflix‚Äôs stale croissant of a TV series, Emily in Paris, for two major awards, snubbing Michaela Coel‚Äôs blistering triumph of what television is even capable of, I May Destroy You, and failing to nominate any of the year‚Äôs Black-led awards contenders for Best Picture: Da 5 Bloods, Judas and the Black Messiah, Ma Rainey‚Äôs Black Bottom, and One Night in Miami.It was certainly the case when three HFPA members took the stage Sunday to address its inclusivity problem. Each delivered a breezy speech so perfunctory, vague, and deflecting that they might as well have been making their own case for negligence and irrelevance. It was truly an embarrassment, such a monstrous whiff that there was no fighting the reflex to laugh.But you could also argue there‚Äôs no punchline here at all.Last week, The Los Angeles Times published a damning investigation into the organization‚Äôs long history of scandal and unscrupulousness, which escalated the backlash.This is not a revelatory characterization for an award organization whose reliably bizarre slate of nominees is universally chalked up to its notorious movie-star obsession‚Äînever forget, Golden Globe nominees Johnny Depp and Angelina for The Tourist‚Äîand whose reputation for trading votes in exchange for lavish gifts and access to celebrities stretches back to Pia Zadora‚Äôs infamous 1982 win. (Apparently voters were flown to Paris to visit the Emily in Paris set, hence those questionable nods.)But having decades of ‚Äúself-dealing‚Äù and ‚Äúethical lapses,‚Äù as the Times characterized them, packaged so incriminatingly on the crest of outrage over nomination slights makes the case (for some) that the Globes should be discredited, not aired on NBC, and not given its glamorous spotlight at the prime of Oscar season‚Äîespecially after reports of its lack of inclusivity.Short of reconfiguring Sunday night‚Äôs ceremony to assert its own legitimacy by giving each award of the night to Michaela Coel for I May Destroy You with a brief pause for a show-stopping rendition of ‚ÄúIt Was Agatha All Along‚Äù by Kathryn Hahn, it‚Äôs unclear if there was anything the HFPA or NBC could have done to correct for the sins of this year‚Äôs nominations or atone for the organization‚Äôs shady practices in any satisfactory way.But even grading on the curve of an attempt to stage a live production like this during the pandemic, the Globes failed to meet even the lowest bar.The irony is that this year‚Äôs hideous mess of a telecast did actually make the case for why award shows matter.An explosive speech on the power of storytelling, diversity, and major platforms by Jane Fonda. The authenticity of stirring moments from the likes of Minari director Lee Isaac Chung and Nomadland director Chlo√© Zhao in their historic wins. The strength and inspiration of Chadwick Boseman‚Äôs widow Taylor Simone Ledward. Or the grace and forward thinking of a community of diverse creators who, while bruised by the myopia and narcissism of an influential organization too inept to mint its potential for good, still showed up for a complicated pandemic award show because they at least knew the power of the stories they were telling. (And, sure, also like winning trophies.)Jane Fonda Calls Out Golden Globes‚Äô Diversity Problems in Powerful Acceptance SpeechBut the point is that, in relying on the labor of others‚Äîparticularly women and people of color‚Äîto do the work it should have been doing all along, the Globes has embarrassed its reputation beyond the forgiveness its designation as ‚ÄúHollywood‚Äôs boozy and kooky nonsense party‚Äù has warranted in its past. If now is not the time to sober up and detail a plan of action, then when?Three HFPA members who came on stage and said two sentences each about doing better. They ended those speeches with, ‚ÄúThank you, and we look forward to a more inclusive future...‚Äù The concept of ‚Äúdoing the bare minimum‚Äù is writing an angry later aghast at how little effort the organization put in. The statement was such a Mad Libs of meaningless buzzwords I wonder if Emily in Paris wrote it.Here‚Äôs the thing about Sunday night‚Äôs telecast: The conversation surrounding the HFPA‚Äôs scandals was so loud there was nothing else about the ceremony that could have possibly superseded it. The fact that, as far as live Hollywood award shows shot on two different coasts in the middle of a pandemic while winners deliver acceptance speeches over weak Zoom connections go, the telecast was perfectly fine doesn‚Äôt even matter.Fey and Poehler were perfectly fine. Their monologue was perfectly fine.They were the first to directly address the inclusivity scandal, with Poehler saying, ‚ÄúLook, a lot of flashy garbage got nominated. But that happens‚Äîthat‚Äôs like their thing. But a number of Black actors and Black-led projects were overlooked.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd look, we all know that award shows are stupid,‚Äù added Fey. ‚ÄúThe point is, even with stupid things, inclusivity is important, and there are no Black members of the Hollywood Foreign Press. I realize, HFPA, maybe you guys didn‚Äôt get the memo because your workplace is the back booth of a French McDonald‚Äôs, but you gotta change that.‚ÄùIt wasn‚Äôt a scorched-earth condemnation, but it also certainly wasn‚Äôt toothless‚Äîand it was funny. It should have been the comedy-tinged appetizer for the meal eventually served by the HFPA, who should have delivered a strong and action-oriented statement that left no question that change was on the horizon. Instead it was like they served the food and then hurriedly cleared the plates before anyone realized the meals were undercooked.In other words, they seemed to hope that a business-as-usual show, as much as that could be staged in these times, would be a distraction: ‚ÄúYes, we‚Äôre probably racist...but look! It‚Äôs Salma Hayek!‚Äù No matter how funny Kristin Wiig and Annie Mumolo are as their Barb and Star Go to Vista Del Mar characters, how deliriously bizarre a bit with Maya Rudolph and Kenan Thompson is, or how unintentionally funny Tracy Morgan‚Äôs mispronunciation of Soul was, there was no distracting from it.In fact, the show‚Äôs best moments drew direct attention to it.The astounding thing about Jane Fonda is that she manages to be an even better version of Jane Fonda every time we need her to be. This year‚Äôs Cecil B. DeMille Award recipient, we knew she would deliver an important speech, but as the Globes backlash intensified, so did the stakes for her remarks. And, wow, did she deliver.It may be the first Globes speech to name-check both Buddha and Tommy Tune, but she also‚Äîand so eloquently‚Äîdrew the connection between Hollywood, platforms like an award-show microphone, and elevating all voices that encapsulated why so many people are so upset about what some might dismiss as a silly, dumb awards ceremony.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a story we‚Äôve been really afraid to see and hear about ourselves and this industry: The story about which voices we respect and elevate and which we tune out,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúA story about who‚Äôs offered a seat at the table and who‚Äôs kept out of the rooms where the decisions are made.‚ÄùIn the classiest move of the night, she then cited the films and TV series, some nominated and some pointedly not, that enlightened her to the experiences of underrepresented people: Nomadland and the wanderers; Minari and immigrants; Judas and the Black Messiah, Small Axe, The United States vs. Billie Holiday, Ma Rainey‚Äôs Black Bottom, and One Night in Miami and what it means to be Black in this country; Ramy and the experience of Muslim Americans; and the snubbed I May Destroy You and surviving sexual violence.It‚Äôs the frustrating thing about the open secret of the Globes being a frivolous awards organization with random nominees and winners. That may be true, but it is also a telecast on NBC that does wield influence.Money is spent on these awards campaigns. Rising stars are given trophies on television, and, when they‚Äôre people like America Ferrera or Gina Rodriguez or Viola Davis or Chlo√© Zhao, it means something to those who are watching at home and see themselves represented. Opportunity is given to winners. Boosts are given to Oscar hopefuls. People watching at home might see a TV series or movie win an award and decide to watch it‚Äîthat on its own matters. Even at the Golden Globes, the image of a storyteller holding a trophy signals that their voice is important.Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Embarrass Hollywood Foreign Press in Golden Globes OpeningIt‚Äôs cool to scoff at the Golden Globes and make a personal pledge to ignore them. But what if there was a demand to make them matter? They already do, but they should earn that privilege. That‚Äôs the great ending line from Fonda‚Äôs speech: ‚ÄúArt has always been not just in step with history, but has led the way. So let‚Äôs be leaders.‚ÄùFor crying out loud, the history-making three-woman slate of directing nominees were three of the five ever nominated in the show‚Äôs 78-year history. Chlo√© Zhao is only the second to win, following Barbra Streisand‚Äôs Yentl victory in 1983. Zhao‚Äôs Nomadland is the first film directed by a woman to ever win Best Picture - Drama. Demand better; don‚Äôt just write it off.An award show like the Golden Globes serves dual purposes. It‚Äôs meant to entertain and it‚Äôs meant to be a catalyst for progress. That sounds pretentious, and there‚Äôs no way around it. But that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs supposed to be OK that the Globes are also a drunken party. That‚Äôs the fun part.This year created great moments of entertainment in spite of impossible circumstances. I would watch tributes to Jane Fonda and Norman Lear for hours. Baron Cohen delivered two great speeches. Andra Day, Rosamund Pike, and Anya Taylor-Joy had those kinds of unexpected (and maybe undeserved???) award-show coming out moments that are thrilling to witness. And may we all watch all future award telecasts either as seemingly high as Jason Sudeikis appeared to be, or at least wearing a pair of Jodie Foster‚Äôs pajamas.Then there was the night‚Äôs emotional highpoint, when Boseman‚Äôs widow delivered powerful words to an audience that needed to hear them. ‚ÄúHe would say something beautiful, something inspiring, something that would amplify that little voice that tells you you can, that tells you to keep going,‚Äù Ledward said. ‚ÄúI don't have his words, but we have to take all the moments to celebrate the ones we love.‚ÄùThe issue with the Globes is how do you square those moments against the unsavory ones. Against its reputation for bad taste (though at least this year‚Äôs winners weren‚Äôt so bad, if the nominations were a bit wild)? Against its failure to course correct after decades of criticism? Against its seeming refusal to see this particular moment surrounding inclusivity as a crisis for the organization?That‚Äôs where the boycotts come in. That‚Äôs where the call for NBC to stop broadcasting the show and give it its power comes in. But that‚Äôs where, at the very least, a demand for change comes in.It‚Äôs tempting to shout, ‚ÄúCancel the Globes!‚Äù But I‚Äôm not sure that‚Äôs a feasible solution. Whatever the HFPA thought it was doing to save itself with Sunday night‚Äôs telecast, however, didn‚Äôt make a case in its own favor. At what was a turning point for the show, it took a nosedive toward more shame. The work from there gets even harder. I still argue it should be done.Anyway, in the spirit of Our Lord and Savior Jane Fonda, we will end this article the way all pieces of good writing should end from now on: ‚ÄúAnd happy birthday to Tommy Tune!‚ÄùSacha Baron Cohen Brutally Mocks Rudy Giuliani in Golden Globes SpeechRead more at The Daily Beast.Got a tip? Send it to The Daily Beast hereGet our top stories in your inbox every day. Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you. Learn more.
